channel.title: Vaccine on Infectious Perspectives
channel.description: Recent content in Vaccine on Infectious Perspectives

item.title: Equity vs. Equality: Modelling Vaccine Distribution in Response to an Influenza Outbreak
item.description: This group project is a collective effort, with contributions from my teammates Minn Thit Aung, Polly Nightingale, Simon Kent, and Xavier Dunn, listed alphabetically.* This post aims to: Find the the basic reproduction number of an hypothetical outbreak Assess the impact of specified vaccination strategies and school closures on an outbreak Offer codes on creating a GIF of an epidemic curve using R Note that this blog is currently under construction.

item.title: Assessing the Non-inferiority of the Single-dose Human Papillomavirus Vaccination Schedule: A Hypothetical Multi-country Cohort Study
item.description: What can you learn from this article? An experimental cohort study design for policy evaluation, where countries made the move from a two-dose to single-dose schedule for national HPV vaccination programmes since 2023. Introduction Since the first licensing of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine in 2006, evidence has been emerging showing that single-dose schedules provide comparable efficacy to the conditional regimens, i.e. two or three doses. In 2022, a review of World Health Organization (WHO) Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (SAGE) concluded that a single-dose HPV vaccine delivers solid protection against HPV.
